We are voting for dferent parties at this election, but we have all come to the dficult decision not to vote Labour.”Former minister Ian Austin, the chairman of Mainstream who quit Labour in disgust over anti-Semitism earlier this year, said: “This is a hard decision for Labour supporters to make.“It was extremely dficult for me and the other former Labour MPs involved too. But the risk is just too great.“If Jeremy Corbyn enters Downing Street on Friday th, it would be a disaster for the United Kingdom.”It came as a veteran Labour spin doctor who advised Gordon Brown as PM last night vowed to vote Tory tomorrow - as he can’t stomach terrorist sympathiser Jeremy Corbyn.Paul Sinclair, a top aide in the Better Together pro-union campaign in , also blasted the Labour leader’s plans for a “dirty deal with Nicola Sturgeon”.He said: “I cannot vote for a Labour Party led by Jeremy Corbyn. He is not of the Labour tradition.“There are many reasons I could lay out. His support for terrorists around the globe. For the IRA. His refusal to take on the anti-Semitism in his party.“The fantasies with which he is trying to con people. The billions he is supposedly going to spend on us all without a clue on how he is going to raise them.“Notes to Santa written this month by five-year-olds have more realism about them than his manesto.”The devastating attack comes the day after Labours Jonathan Ashworth was caught saying he didnt think Labour would win the election - and voters cant stand Mr Corbyn.The Shadow Health Secretary was caught on a taped call telling a pal that the “civil service machine” would move “pretty quickly move to safeguard security”Mr Corbyn reaches No.He also said his party’s chances of winning seats in the North were “abysmal” and that he “can’t see” Mr Corbyn getting to No.However, Mr Ashworth later told the BBC that the comments were simply banter between him and a Tory activist friend who had subsequently made him look a plonker.Seizing on the comments today, Mr Johnson said thatBrits vote for anyone other than the Tories: “This country would be led by a Hamas-backing, IRA supporting, anti-Semitism condoning appeaser of the Kremlin - which is what he is, look at the record.“Butyou doubt me, listen to what his health spokesman said today, Jon Ashworth.“He revealed that he thinks his own leader is a security risk and I think it couldnt be clearer than that.”The Tory boss made the comments at a JCB factory in Uttoxeter, Staffordshire, after crashing through a Styrofoam brick-wall, with ‘Deadlock emblazoned on it, in a Union Flag digger.The PM blasted the leftie-leader as a “Hamas-backing” IRA supporter as he lept on the humiliating blunder by Mr Ashworth two days before the election. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mystery father christmas leaving wrapped gifts for anyone who finds them across town to make their day

title: amazon courier caught on camera stamping on customers parcel to make it fit through letter box
story: The dopey courier was caught red-handed when he was filmed damaging the parcel by the buyer’s home CCTV cameras.The driver can be seen repeatedly mangling the white package with his hands.But unbelievably, he then places the item on the floor, before repeatedly stamping on it in a bid to make it fit through the buyer’s letterbox.The shocked Amazon customer posted the footage to Twitter and shared her shocking delivery experience.She wrote: “AmazonUK@amazon This is how I received my parcel last night. my parcel was trod on and smashed into pieces.“I’m guessing amazon Grays Essex DEPOT need to do a full training course for their drivers to learn how to deliver a parcel.”In reply to the post, the company said: “Were sorry to hear your product was damaged! This is certainly not what we expect for our customers.“Please share your order details with us here, so we can get this matter escalate.”Meanwhile, other customers have revealed on social media how desperate couriers are dumping Christmas parcels in bushes, wheelie bins, electric boxes and on doorsteps as they try to get offload packages.Some have complained of fragile deliveries dumped over fences, signatures forged to say they’ve been delivered - while some have found their boxes floating in pondsCitizens Advice says problems with parcels cost consumers at least £ million last year.The average cost to the inidual who had to pay to fix a parcel problem is £..This could include making telephone calls, replacing damaged or lost items, or travel tothe item in person or drop off at a depot.One person said on Twitter: “My wish is that every parcel from pretty little thing ends up thrown in my pond, oh wait...that’s already been granted... times this year...I love soaking clothes.”As Black Friday and Cyber Monday deliveries arrive this week to shoppers, Citizens Advice has found that problems with parcels affect over halfof those who shopped online in the past year.Gillian Guy, Chief Executive of Citizens Advice, said the problem was incredibly frustrating for customers:She said: “More of us now rely on parcel delivery services as we shop online for convenience and to access the best deals. Around % of UK adults received an online order in the last year.“Problems with parcels can be incredibly frustrating, and can be especially disruptive for people who rely on deliveries like people with disabilities.“The scale of these problems doesn’t come down just to bad practice - it indicates a wider problem with the parcel market as a whole. Right now parcel companies don’t always act in the best interest of consumers. “That’s why we’re asking the Competition and Markets Authority to review this to make sure it works for people using it.”An Amazon spokesperson told The Sun Online: “We have very high standards for our delivery service providers and expect every package to be handled with care.Weve notied the right teams internally and will work with the customer directly on matters related to their package delivery.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: they merriam webster word year sam smith
story: Merriam-Webster announced the honor on Wednesday, saying that online searches for the word increased by more than  percent in .“English famously lacks a gender-neutral singular pronoun to correspond neatly with singular pronouns like everyone or someone, and as a consequence they has been used for this purpose for over  years,” a statement from the company read.“More recently, though, they has also been used to refer to one person whose gender identity is non-binary, a sense that is increasingly common in published, edited text, as well as social media and in daily personal interactions between English speakers.”There was a spike in searches for the word in September when pop star Sam Smith told fans that their preferred pronouns were “they” and “them.” Smith said the decision came after a “letime of being at war with my gender.”Searches also increased in January thanks to model Oslo Grace, who identies as non-binary and walks in both men’s and women’s shows.Another look-up spike occurred in April, when U.S. Rep. Pramila Jayapal, D-Washington, got emotional while talking of her gender-nonconforming child during a House committee hearing as she advocated for LGBT rights legislation.As a result of the increased awareness around the word being used in this context, Merriam-Webster recently added a new definition to its online dictionary to reflect use of “they” as relating to a person whose gender identity is non-binary.Peter Sokolowski, Merriam-Webster’s editor at large, told the Associated Press the word -- as well as other non-binary pronouns that have gained traction in recent years -- is “here to stay”.The runner-ups for this year’s nod included quid pro quo”, “impeach”, and “crawdad,” the latter a word in the title of Delia Evans best-selling novel, “Where the Crawdads Sing.” The Top  also included “egregious,” “clemency” and “the”.“They” follows “justice”, ’s word of the year, as well as other recent winners such as “feminism”, “surreal”, “-ism”, and “culture”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: grandad supermarket freezer door fell on him
story: Stuart Clegg, , from Longridge in Lancashire, said the freak accident had turned his world upside down and means he now struggles to carry out basic tasks.The orced dad-of-four needs daily care from his elderly mum and has been forced to give up work as a bookkeeper following the  incident that changed his le.Mr Clegg said: The pain is so bad that I cant do everyday things like carry a shopping basket.I cant drive for a long at all because I get shooting pains in my neck, shoulder, arms and all the way down to my fingers.My mum has to come help me all the time. Im an adult and I shouldnt be like this.I have grandchildren and I cant even pick them up or interact with them anymore because of whats happened.The freak incident happened at a Booths supermarket in May .Mr Clegg, a granddad-of-six, said he was leaning into the fridge when the glass door he had just opened came loose and fell on him like a guillotine.He said: It came down on top of me and pinned me to the floor...I couldnt move.I thought bloody hell what on earth has happened here  You dont expect to go into a supermarket and be floored by a fridge door. I was shocked and shaken up.Mr Clegg said a number of staff members came to his help and askedhe needed an ambulance but he was able to get himself to hospital on his own.After being discharged, the -year-old had to later have two discs removed from his neck after complaining of severe neck and nerve pain.He now has to visit hospital every six weeks for nerve blocking injections to try and relieve the pain.He was taking legal action against the supermarket  months later when an X-ray revealed he had a mild form of arthritis in his neck which he was unaware of.The former bookmaker said the supermarket’s lawyers claimed the surgery he had was inevitable and the fridge incident had merely accelerated the need for it.As a result Mr Clegg said he was only offered £, compensation but would have been offered nearer £, had he not been diagnosed with arthritis.He said: I feel like I have been poorly treated.Beforehand I lived a normal le but now everything has changed...I can barely do anything for myself.A Booths spokesman said: I can confirm that Mr Clegg unfortunately suffered an accident within our Longridge Store in May .Subsequently Mr Clegg instructed solicitors to act on his behalf who brought a claim against the Company for which liability was admitted.The claim was settled in the sum of £, in full and final settlement.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unemployed couple seven children gofundme
story: Ryan Rodgers, , and Jenny Grimes, , from Liverpool, say they struggle to survive on £ a month benefits after their Universal Credit payment was slashed.The couple say they are forced to rely on food banks, charities and help from pals and relatives to feed their kids, who are all under seven years old.Mr Rodgers says he suffers from depression and anxiety and became an alcoholic, but has now beaten the booze.But Ms Grimess mum Shelly Grattan insisted the couple’s GoFundMe appeal to pay for Christmas is a con -  and that Mr Rodgers would spend the money on alcohol and cigarettes.On the GoFundMe page, Ms Grimes wrote: We are a young couple with seven children trying to get back on our feet after becoming homeless having to start all over again from fresh.We have been benefit capped to the bare minimum and we are really struggling to get by.Our situation is being much more a struggle with Christmas being only a few weeks away.We feel really ashamed to have to do this as weve never had to do anything like this before.I hate to have to do this and its took a lot for me to actually do it, but there is only so much we can do as a family.Any help at all is very much appreciated, evenyou could point me in the direction of getting some help. Thank you.The couple have raised £, so far.The family-of-nine - Ellie, seven, six-year-old twins Kenzie and Kelsie, Laysie, four, Archie, two and two twin boys, Tobie and Rylie, aged seven months - live in a three-bedroom home, which costs £ a month in rent.Mr Rodgers used to work as a waiter, but has been washing cars to pay their electricity bills.The couple said their children wanted for nothing until Mr Rodgers lost his job over a health scare last year.But his mother-in-law, Ms Grattan, told MailOnline: Ryan is a feckless liar who is trying to con the public into giving him money which he will just pour down his throat.No one should give him any money as he has a drink problem and thats where it will all go. He will spend it all on booze.Anyone who has donated to the GoFundMe page should ask for their money back. He is conning the public with a sob story that is not true.Ms Grimes sister, Jo Jo Grimes, said Mr Rodgers, the son of a police sergeant, is feckless and workshy.She added: He leaves the house at am in the morning and comes back late at night off his head on drink. He has a big drink problem and he also spends most of their benefit money on weed.Jenny did leave him once about four years ago but they got back together.He is just bad news and the public should not fall for his sob story.But the couple insist they are ashamed to set up their GoFundMe appeal and deny their familys accusations.Ms Grimes has been forced to defend her partner after her own family branded him an alcoholic.She said: “Our own family is commenting and telling people that Ryan is an alcoholic, he used to have a problem with drink but he’s not drunk for ages.“People are also suggesting things about drugs which is ridiculous, I’ve not touched a drug in my le and I wouldn’t let anything like that anywhere near my kids. I think drugs are disgusting.“We are good parents who are on benefits, receiving the most minimal amount of money from the government, we can’t survive on just this.“We’ve had lots of nasty texts, emails and phone calls, I believe a relative is actually giving out my number for people to text us abuse because we don’t get on.People are telling us that they’re reporting us to the CPS and social services.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris lots to offer young people
story: As a spec-free, state-educated young woman, my voting intentions tend to be greeted with a mixture of shock and resentment. By not supporting Jeremy Corbyn and his Communist buddies, I am - I am told - an “age traitor”. Boris is for boomers, the thinking goes, and Corbyn is for us.But scratch the surface and you’ll find that the Prime Minister - a man who made his name as mayor of London - has rather a lot to offer us young folk. And Jeremy Corbyn - a Marxist straight from the s- might just make our lives a hell of a lot worse.Take, for example, the issue the vast majority of young people say matters to them most: housing.If you’re a young private renter, Corbyn’s radical plan to crackdown on “dodgy” landlords sounds really rather good.But there’s a serious catch. If landlords could be forced by the government to sell their homes to tenants at a price dictated by the Government, the buy-to-let market would collapse. And fast.In a few pockets of the country, where housing supply is plentul, that would be great. With landlords out of the picture, those desperate to get on the property ladder might stand a chance.In most of Britain, though, the picture wouldn’t be so rosy. Where available housing is precious and most people can’t afford to get on the housing ladderprivate renting is a blessing. And a collapse in the buy-to-let market would hike the price of it.So under Corbyn’s “fairer Britain”, those right at the start of their careers would soon be priced out of metropolitan areas.Then take university fees. Again, the idea of “free uni” sounds very tempting indeed. But under Corbyn’s regime, university tuition wouldn’t suddenly become free. It would just be paid for by the tax-payer instead of the student.What does that mean in practice  Well, it means that the  per cent of young people who opt to get a job end up at  would end up massively subsidising the  per cent who choose to enjoy three years of student le. I loved my time at uni, but I don’t see why my  year old cousin - who’s been working his socks off in the navy for three years - should be forced to pay for it.And evenyou are a student or planning to go to university, Corbyn won’t help you in any real sense. If students don’t contribute to their own education, universities suddenly have a lot less money. Which means they can’t admit as many teenagers.In Scotland, for example, where tuition has been “free” for years, fewer and fewer young people are going to university. And because the middle classes know how to game the system, it tends to be disadvantaged kids who get let down.Andyou work for yourself, which around % of Generation Z would like to do, Labour’s radical tax plan certainly isn’t for you.Even though Jeremy Corbyn has promised that only the richest five per cent of workers will face higher bills, new analysis shows that self-employed workers earning much less could be £, a year worse off under the new rules. And sole traders - ie. young, ambitious entrepreneurs who pay themselves lower salaries in order to invest in their businesses - would suffer the most.Boris Johnson might not be a hit at Glastonbury. But like a true One Nation Conservative, he believes in opportunity. And his pragmatic schemes, like % deposit mortgages, would give hard working young people a proper leg up in le.I don’t hunt, I don’t shoot, and I wouldn’t be seen dead in tweed. But I believe that a country can only succeed when ambitious young people are encouraged by the state to spread their wings and fly. Not given countless handouts by a bankrupt Government.So tomorrow, I’ll be voting Conservative with pride.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: election boris bright future corbyn lights out
story: It is vital you go out, whatever the weather, and vote Tory.You may never have done so before. But it has NEVER been more important. Well, here’s a reminder: In  the global financial crisis and Labour’s scandalous over-spending left us heading for bankruptcy. Labour was borrowing nearly £billion a WEEK and left incoming Tories a snarky note: “Dear Chief Secretary. I’m afraid there is no money.”They thought it was FUNNY. The cost was nine long years of cuts, vital to get our finances back in order. These are now presented as a cruel Tory “choice”. That is nonsense. They had no alternative.But, yes, public services have struggled. The NHS is short-staffed and cannot keep pace with an older, sicker and rapidly expanding population. Police cuts have hurt the fight against crime.Homes are far too expensive for young people, particularly in the South. Many of those don’t recall Labour’s financial disaster. They just want change and an economic stake in society. But they and too many others who will vote Labour because they are sick of “Tory cuts” forget why they happened:Labour wrecked the economy. The Tories had to fix it.Boris is a dferent Tory, unafraid to spend big to pump le back into “left-behind” communities.His economic programme is far more lavish than that of Theresa May or David Cameron. But you are going to have to vote for it.Too many think they voted for Brexit once, it didn’t happen and they can’t be bothered voting any more. That all politicians are liars, so why trust any  Or that Nigel Farage has promised to deliver Brexit too, so you’ll vote for him.These would be disastrous errors.Farage’s party will not win seats. A vote for his Brexit Party is one lost to the Tories, as several Farage candidates have now admitted.Andyou’re a Remainer Tory who dislikes Boris, a vote for the Lib-Dems is not a “free hit”. title: wildlife pics tigers lions panthers photography kent
story: Fashion and portrait photographer, Perou, spent a year capturing the big cats on camera before ending up with these breathtaking images.Speaking of the project, Perou said: “Most people photograph big cats from a distance and in daylight for a good reason.But I decided to enter the Lions’ den, literally not metaphorically, and so I set up a photo studio to photograph these magnicent animals much the same way I would photograph a rock star or a fashion model.The cats were allowed to become familiar with my equipment, and more importantly, they could leave at any time they wished.Over some months, I spent hours hanging out with the cats, often turning up at feeding time, so they associated my presence, my scent and the equipment with their favourite food.“The cats would come and go as they pleased and took their own time to sit for me. Each of the cats has its own, very inidual personality, and so each species of cat provided new challenges or experiences.”

title: election jeremy corbyn nightmare rod liddle
story: I dream I’ve just woken up and I look at the clock. It says “Friday th”. Then I hear a horrible cackling — and, OMG, it’s Diane Abbott standing by my bed, her face split open with mirth.“We’re in charge now!” she shrieks: “Ha ha ha ha ha.” And then the rest of the ghouls appear.Magic Grandpa Jeremy Corbyn, smirking through his beard, wearing his Lenin hat. Jo Swinson of the Lib Dems like a Girl Guide Leader from Hades. And then — grinning like Janette Krankie on acid — Nicola Sturgeon of the SNP.I try to hide under the covers but Diane pulls them back. “We’re in charge now,” she repeats. “And first we’re going to wreck Brexit. And then we’re going to wreck the country. Ha ha ha ha.”Friday, December  is the day we find out who will be ruling us for the next five years. And my nightmare could quite possibly come true.I’ve been saying for ages that the idiotic Corbyn could win this election — without actually winning any more seats.It is an incredibly precarious position for Boris Johnson and the Conservatives — and thus for Brexit.The polls seem to be tightening. The Conservatives haven’t run a terribly good campaign, it’s true.All it needs is another drop in the Tory lead of one per cent and we would be heading for a hung Parliament.That almost certainly means a government led by Corbyn, with support from the Lib Dems and the SNP. It would definitely mean an end for Brexit.The democratic decision we took three years ago would be forgotten. At best there would be ANOTHER referendum.Almost certainly rigged by Labour and the Lib Dems to ensure that, this time, the right side won, ie, their side.They have no respect whatsoever for that democratic mandate. They are very clear about that. But there will be even worse to come.Labour will usher in a ruinous economic programme which the country cannot possibly afford.Our entrepreneurs will flee the country. We’ll be back in huge debt once again. Spending on stuff we cannot afford.Labour plans to spend TWENTY EIGHT times as much money as the ConservativesWorst of all, we will be led by a halfwit who supports every enemy known to this country.You name a terrorist cell or a vile, authoritarian country and mad old Jezza will at some point have offered it support.From the IRA to the genocidal Islamists Hamas, from Cuba to Iran.The brilliant website Guido Fawkes has detailed all the times Corbyn has stuck up for terrorists or horrible totalitarian governments. Gawd help us, the list is almost endless.This is a bloke who has said he wishes Nato didn’t exist. That’s the military alliance which has kept peace for  years!But don’t take my word for it. Just this week yet another Labour MP was caught moaning about how truly bloody awful Corbyn was.Jonathan Ashworth said voters were turned off by the man and that the prospects for Labour were “dire”.He added: “I’m helping colleagues, banging on about the NHS for them, but it’s awful for them, and it’s the combination of Corbyn and Brexit . . . outside of the city seats . . . it’s abysmal out there . . . they can’t stand Corbyn and they think Labour’s blocked Brexit.”That’s not “Tory lies”, as the lefties always say when someone takes a pop at the old scrote.That’s a member of his own front-bench team. But then a good two thirds of Labour MPs can’t stand Corbyn and think he would be awful for this country.As Boris Johnson said, Ashworth was only saying what hundreds of Labour candidates and millions of voters were thinking.You wonder why some of those candidates don’t have the courage of their convictions and stand down.In fact, plenty have already done so. Ivan Lewis, for example, who has urged everybody to vote Conservative.Then there was John Woodcock and Ian Austin. Both former Labour MPs, moderates. They even made placards telling people to vote Tory.More MPs left Labour long ago — such as Chuka Umunna, who is now standing as a Liberal Democrat, and Brexiteer Kate Hoey can’t bring herself to support the party she served for  years.The man and his retinue of Trots — John McDonnell, Rebecca Long-Bailey , the ghastly Diane Abbott — are a laughing stock. Except I don’t find very much to laugh about, to tell you the truth.And along with Labour and the Lib Dems will come more stupid, socially isive identity politics. The whole country ided up into competing victimhoods.Gay, transgender, black, Asian. Asthese were the things which define us as human beings.But then that’s the infantile and damaging way the Left sees the world.Given all this, you might think it incredible that Corbyn could ever get the keys to No Downing Street. So many people despise the bloke.And that’s before we factor in his repellent anti-Semitism .And you might look at the polls and think — well, the Tories still have a decent lead. Nothing much to worry about.It won’t be Friday th or Nightmare On Abbott Street. It might well be Groundhog Day, but that’s preferable. But this is the big problem for BoJo and his Conservative team. Complacency. The suspicion on the part of the electorate that Corbyn could never actually win. When he could win all too easily — and don’t forget, the opinion polls are very often wrong.The other problem for the Tories is, of course, the Brexit Party. They are still fielding candidates in seats up and down the country — seats which the Tories need to win in order to form a government.Some senior figures in the Brexit Party have already said they would be far better off backing the Tories in order to get Brexit done.But Brexit Party boss Nigel Farage will not listen to them.So we have the terrible situation where people might vote for the Brexit Party in order to make sure we leave the European Union — but in doing so actually STOP Brexit from occurring.Becausethe Brexit Party takes lots of votes from the Tories, that lets in Labour and the Lib Dems through the back door. And the result  No Brexit.It’s in those seats in the North and Midlands where the Conservatives are most vulnerable to a high Brexit Party vote.This is a crucial election. Not just for Brexit, but for Britain’s future.That means a vote for the Conservatives, no matter how much that sticks in the craw.I’ve mentioned before that the only time I voted Tory I felt pretty glum afterwards.But this time there really is no alternative except in a tiny handful of seats where the Tories cannot possibly win.Once this election is out of the way, we need a new party to provide opposition to the Tories.A party that will replace Labour. For me, that’s the Social Democrats. But we’re not at that stage yet.For now it’s a case of walking to the polling booth, holding your nose and voting Blue.You decide our government. You may have your doubts about our democracy — I don’t blame you! You may feel uneasy voting Tory — don’t blame you for that, either.But you hold the destiny of our country in your hands.Indeed, when you put that cross in a box, you ARE the government. The person who decides what is best for our country.So make your vote count, please — and banish those nightmares for ever. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: exit poll local general elections results accurate
story: But how do they work and when is it coming out An exit poll is a survey of a small proportion of voters leaving polling stations across the UK.Researchers ask which party the  inidual voted for, as well as their age, race and gender.The form is completed anonymously and placed in a ballot box.It is primarily used to calculate turnout and electoral swing - the extent of change in voter support compared to the previous election.Data cant be released before the polls have closed.Due to only a small sample of voters filling out questionnaires, those doing so are likely to be younger, so this may skewer results.Also, voters head to the polls at dferent times so a single exit poll may not give a true reflection of the overall outlook of the national vote.However, pollsters tend toto the same polling stations at the same times at each election.And by comparing these results it is possible to work out how voting has changed in that particular constituency.A famous example of an election poll error happened in .Two exit polls predicted a hung parliament - but the actual vote revealed the Tory government under John Major held their position.Investigations later revealed a number of causes that led to the miscalculation - including the shy Tory factor and inadequate demographic data.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what coalition government how work
story: The Conservatives and the Lib Dems  pact was the first coalition since the end of the Second World War. Heres what you need to know...An overall majority needed by political parties to win a General Election is  seats.When a General Election results in no single political party winning an overall majority in the House of Commons, this is known as a hung parliament.Parties may decide to join together temporarily in order to obtain a clear majority.In what is known as a confidence and supply deal, a smaller party can agree to support its partner in budget bills and other cornerstone legislation — but it is not a formal arrangement.Northern Irelands DUP, which won ten seats in the  snap election, entered into talks with the Conservatives to prop up Theresa May in government on this kind of deal.A full coalition involves a definite pact between parties to form a majority.A coalition government may also be formed during a national dficulty such as a war or economic crisis.Bookmakers dont appear to be staking much on a coalition government resulting from the December  poll.New polling commissioned by the New Statesman shows that every possible coalition combination is deeply unpopular with voters.The survey by GQR revealed all options had a net negative approval rating, with a coalition between the Conservatives and the Brexit Party the least unpopular among them.However, Boris Johnson has already dismissed a partnership between the two.The  General Election in the UK failed to produce an overall majority.The result on May,   was the first hung parliament in  years, and the first full coalition since .It sparked a series of negotiations that ended in the forming of the first coalition since the Second World War.The Conservatives, led by David Cameron, won the largest number of seats but fell short of the number required for an overall majority.Senior figures from both Labour, who had lost power, and the Conservatives met with representatives from the Lib Dems, led by Nick Clegg, with the aim of forming a coalition government.On May ,  a coalition deal between the Conservatives and the Lib Dems was signed.While Cameron became Prime Minister, Liberal Democrat leader Nick Clegg was appointed as Deputy Prime Minister.Before , coalition governments tend title: why pencils general election pens
story: But why do we always use pencils It is a tradition in the UK for voters to mark ballot papers with lead pencils, which are supplied in polling booths.This is the same in local elections, general elections and referendums.Pencils are preferred for historic and practical reasons.Ink can smudge, dry out or spill over the paper, which could invalidate a persons vote.When the paper is folded over, pen ink might transfer into another box, making it look like the voter has voted more than once.Some people have questioned whether pencils make fraud more likely.In theory a voters X could be rubbed out and replaced with a vote for another candidate.At the EU referendum, police were called to a polling station after a voter lent another his pen amid rumours of a conspiracy to erase pencil marks.The Electoral Commission says measures are in place to stop anyone tampering with ballot papers.It said: The use of pencils does not in itself increase the likelihood of electoral fraud.Legislation has built specic safeguards into the process, such as the requirement for seals to be attached to ballot boxes at the close of poll.By law, campaigners are also entitled to be present at that stage and to attach their own sealsthey wish. At the start of the count, they can then observe those same seals being broken.Tampering with ballot papers is a serious offence andanyone has evidence that ballot papers are being tampered with, they should report this to the police.Yes, you can use a penyou wish.Pencils are supplied at the polling station - often attached to a string in each booth.But there is nothing to stop voters from bringing their own pen.The important thing is to clearly mark your voting intention on the paper.If you are registered to vote you should have received a polling card in the post that tells you where your nearest polling station is.Find out who is standing in your area by typing your postcode on the Your Vote Matters website, which will also tell you where to vote.Polls are open until pm.Carefully check the guidance on how to fill in the ballot paper.Polling station staff can helpyou are unsure, but will only advise on how to vote - not who to vote for. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.  more than the general election two years ago when they received .The detailed seat-by-seat analysis means every vote will make all the dference  Brits want to avoid another hung parliament - with just  seats currently in it.Boris has hammered home his warning of a clear and present danger of a Corbyn governmentBrits dont check the Conservative box on their ballot paper.The Tories are concerned a Labour victory is “much closer” than their supporters think due to tactical voting for Remainers.On October , MPs approved the PMs call for an election to be held on December .It was Mr Johnsons fourth attempt to have Parliament agree to an election after the Labour Party blocked the vote three times.Parliament shut down from November .When this happens every seat in the House of Commons becomes vacant with those wishing to remain as MPs having to stand in the forthcoming election.The UK can leave before that dateMr Johnsons deal is passed in Parliament.The Prime Minister had vowed to push for an electionthe EU granted a three-month extension for his Brexit bill.Mr Johnson sent a letter to the EU requesting a delay until January  after he was compelled to do so when the Benn Act was passed MPs on October .On October , the EU granted the UKs request for a flextension until January , .

title: britain one national freedom other brexit paralysis
story: One path leads to British independence under Conservative leader Boris Johnson - but the other path follows a far darker course into chaos under Jeremy Corbyn’s Marxist cult.A Johnson victory should usher in a new age of prosperity and national freedom, while a Corbyn triumph will end in Brexit paralysis and financial bankruptcy.A Tory Government will ensure that Britain remains an advanced western economy, where taxes are kept down and enterprise encouraged, where as a Labour Government will turn our country into a basket case, wrecked by trade union bullying and the confiscation of wealth.Every citizen who genuinely cares about our future and cherishes British values therefore has a duty to vote against Corbyn’s hard-left Labour.In practice, that requires everyone - from Tory Remainers to hard Brexiteers - backing the Tories - because only a vote for Boris Johnson can be guaranteed to prevent a brutal Corbyn regime.A vote for the Liberal Democrats or the Brexit Party is not a wasted vote in this election -its something far more dangerous.It is effectively an act of support for Corbyn, forthere is another hung Parliament he will almost certainly emerge as the new Prime Minister.The same is true of moderate, centrist Labour voters who kid themselves that they can back their local Labour candidate while still hoping to avoid the calamity of a Corbyn Government.This is just irresponsible self-deceit. Every vote for Labour brings the Corbyn revolution a step closer.That catastrophe could easily happen this week.In recent opinion polls, the Tories have maintained a consistent lead over Labour by about  per cent - enough for a comfortable majority.But in some surveys, the gap has fallen to just  points, while one poll at the weekend suggested a Conservative majority of just .Moreover, as the last two General Elections proved, the polls can be badly wrong. The result this time could go down to the wire.What the country needs to ensure Corbyn’s defeat is a vast coalition of voters united by the one aim of keeping him out of Downing Street.This was meant to be the Brexit election but it has rightly turned into a referendum on Corbyn’s spectacular unfitness for high office.And the only result should be a wholesale rejection of his bid for power.To achieve that, all anti-Corbyn voters – no matter what their past allegiances or their personal hostility to Johnson – must vote tactically for the Conservatives.Jeremy Corbyn and his shadow Chancellor John McDonnell must be stoppedThroughout the campaign, Remain supporters have talked feverishly of the potential for anti-Tory tactical voting to stop Brexit.But far more potent would be a wave of pro-Tory tactical voting to keep out Corbyn.At the heart of such a drive must lie the millions of decent, patriotic voters in Labour’s heartlands of the North and the Midlands, who have backed the party all their lives but are now profoundly disillusioned with Corbyn.If they held their noses and supported Johnson, then Labour would face annihilation.There are already signs that this could be happening.The so-called “Red Wall” of around  Labour marginals from Yorkshire to Wales, characterised by seats like Bolsover in Derbyshire and Crewe in Cheshire, appears to be crumbling.If a new army of Red Tory voters materialises on Thursday, the damage to Corbyn could be phenomenal.This week were reports that Labour are even in trouble in Leigh, where Joanne Platt has a majority of almost , and which is only th on the Tories’ target list.Similarly, the latest poll in the Lincolnshire port of Grimsby, which has been held by Labour for generations, shows a big lead for the Tories.This mood of revolt against political loyalties was captured in the words of one café worker in Labour-held Wrexham, North Wales, who said at the weekend: “I’ve always voted Labour and my family always voted Labour. On Thursday I shall be voting Tory.”People like her recognise that traditional Labour – the party of Clem Attlee, John Smith and Tony Blair – is now dead, replaced by a dogmatic, intolerant movement dedicated to the overthrow of capitalism.The election campaign has only reinforced Labour’s unfitness for office.Lavish pledges of free services and extravagant spending increases have been dished out like confetti, shattering the last remnants of the party’s economic credibility.Meanwhile, Labour has nothing coherent to say about Brexit beyond the threat of yet more dither and delay.It is no wonder that the five million Labour voters who backed Leave in the  referendum are in such despair.Boris himself put it well on a visit to Grimsby yesterday when he said that Labour’s Brexit stance represented “the great betrayal, orchestrated from Islington by politicians who sneer at your values and ignore your votes.”But it is not just Leave voters who should back the Tories. Remainers who loathe the idea of a Corbyn regime should do so as well.A hard-left Government is too big a price for stopping Brexit, for which the British people democratically voted three years ago.The arch pro-EU Tory rebel Dominic Grieve, now standing as an independent in his Beaconsfield constituency, said recently that he was “absolutely satisfied that Mr Corbyn would be a disaster in Downing Street.”Yet Grieve is making that dire possibility more likely by trying to siphon off votes from the Tory party.Indeed, all the opposition parties are acting as Corbyn’s allies, whatever their protestations.Nigel Farage’s Brexit party, in particular, could still badly split the anti-Corbyn vote in a string of Northern and Midlands seats, like Hartlepool.The latest poll in the constituency shows the Brexit Party on  per cent and the Tories on  per cent, a far higher combined total of Labour’s  per cent.In Doncaster North, held by Ed Miliband, Labour is on  per cent against a combined total of  per cent for the Brexit Party and the Conservatives.Further south, a vote for Jo Swinson’s Liberal Democrats is realistically a vote for Corbyn, just as in Scotland, support for the SNP will help to propel Corbyn into Downing Street.The choice is stark. Our country’s security, liberty and growth can only be secured by theof a Conservative Government.There is nothing to fear from the continuation in office of Boris Johnson, who stands in the long tradition of one-nation Conservatism epitomised by Benjamin Disraeli and Winston Churchill.But there is everything to fear from Corbyn’s ascent to power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is hung parliement minority government 2019
story: Heres what you need to know.The House of Commons has  constituencies and a party must secure  MPs to create a majority government.If one party has more than half of Parliament, they can pass whatever laws they want without the assistance of any other party —their backbenchers dont rebel.A minority government is usually run by the party with the most seats, but they are not guaranteed to win votes alone because they still have less than half the total number of MPs.Theresa Mays election gamble lost her the majority in , so she formed a minority government with the help of the Democratic Unionist Party,Her Conservative party had  seats leaving them eight short of an overall majority, while the Northern Irish party has  seats.Speaking outside No., Prime Minister Theresa May said: “We will continue to work with our friends and allies in the Democratic Unionist Party in particular.“Our two parties have enjoyed a strong relationship over many years, and this gives me the confidence to believe that we will be able to work together in the interests of the whole United Kingdom.”Boris Johnson will be hoping to gain more than  seats so he has a wider margin for error when passing his Brexit deal.On his final day of campaiging Boris said he is fighting for every vote, as there is a risk of another hung parliament.The pollsters, who have analysed more than , voter interviews over the past week, calculated the Tories would win  seats and Labour .A -seat majority would be the best Tory result since Margaret Thatchers showing in  - but it is sharply down from the -seat victory margin that was being forecast just two weeks ago.Chris Curtis, YouGovs political research manager, said: The margins are extremely tight and small swings in a small number of seats, perhaps from tactical voting and a continuation of Labours recent upward trend, means we cant currently rule out a hung parliament.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: big beasts set lose seats
story: NewsBig beasts tipped to lose seats in election - from Dominic Raab to Dennis SkinnerHere are the areas where the latest YouGov MRP poll predicts some big names could take a fall - as marginal the gap between Labour and the Tories narrows ahead of the general electionShareCommentsByTalia Shadwell:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsLabour faces pressure to give the Lib Dems a clear run at Dominic Raab "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A fresh opinion poll saw gap between the Tories and Labour narrow as the parties unleash a full frontal assault to take marginal seats in the election battleaposs final front.Experts are forecasting Labour will not gain enough support to put the Conservativesapos hold on power in peril. Butthe predictions play out, it could see some top Tory figures ousted - with No-Deal Brexiteer Foreign Secretary Dominic Raabaposs Surrey safe seat now looking vulnerable. The pollsters are attributing the blow to the Toriesapos campaign to the nationwide tactical voting campaign targeting pro-Remain marginal seats.Labour has gained two seats in the latest YouGov MRP prediction since the last poll two weeks ago - but some key red strongholds are also in jeopardy.The highly anticipated poll predicts Boris Johnson is still likely to win the general election with a majority of . The margin of error also means that experts cannot rule out a hung parliament. But the Tories are already preparing for major upsets. The party is said to already be privately predicting Cabinet Minister Theresa Villiers’ Chipping Barnet seat could be lost to Labour after she held by just over  votes last time. Labour has also been pouring resources into Tory Justine Greening’s old seat of Putney which looks set for a red takeover, according to the poll. YouGov predicts tactical voting in heavily pro-Remain seats could see Tories lose control in Chipping Barnett and Putney. Labour is expected to hold key battleground seat Kensington by a whisker again after taking it from the Tories last election by just  votes. Here are the high-profile seats the polls predict could tip... Dominic Raab, Tory foreign Secretary - Esher and Walton In  Dominic Raab won the Surrey safe seat with a majority of more than ,.Pollster analysis suggests the tactical voting campaign has taken a stick to his support and Labour is facing pressure to prod its supporters to give the Lib Dems their vote to topple the Foreign Secretary. The campaign to oust the Tories is playing out in marginal seats around the country as voters are urged to abandon tribal allegiances and support the party with the greatest chance of stealing a win. Mr Raab voted Remain at the  EU Referendum but has since proved himself a No Deal-backing Brexiteer in Boris Johnsonaposs Cabinet. The YouGov MRP model shows tactical voting is producing a sht towards the Lib Dems, with the party now on % and closing the gap on the Conservativesapos %. Theresa Villiers, Tory cabinet minister - Chipping Barnet   The Tories are already privately predicting they have lost the seat she held by -odd votes last time. She is only two points behind her pro-Remain Labour rival Emma Whysall in the north London battleground, which is a Remain area. Iain Duncan Smith, Tory - Chingford and Woodford Green  The welfare slasher and former Tory Party leader has a narrow two-point majority over his Labour rival. The seat on the border of East London and Essex has been a safe Tory seat since its creation in . Mr Duncan Smith has held the seat ever since, but his stronghold is looking set to change hands. YouGov is attributing his potential fall to demographic changes in the area costing the Conservatives its advantage in the area. Dennis Skinner, Labour - Bolsover  Labouraposs aposBeast of Bolsoverapos is predicted to lose his seat after nearly half a century. He has held the advantage since the constituency was created in , but his power showed signs of teetering in the  General Election when his majority fell below , for the first time. Reports suggest the Brexit debate has tested some former miners in the Derbyshire constituency which overwhelmingly voted to leave the EU. Skinneraposs Bolsover seat is predicted to go Tory, as his rival Mark Fletcher gains a three-point majority in the prediction. Caroline Flint, Labour - Don Valley  The Conservatives are predicted to steal the South Yorkshire seat the veteran Labour MP has held since . The Tories are predicted to cause a major upset for the left as Labour struggles to hold onto majority leave areas in the North. She has put in long service for Labour but her Don Valley seat is predicted to go Tory, despite her vowing to back a Brexit deal on behalf of her leave-voting constituency. Phil Wilson, Labour - Sedgefield  The veteran Labour MP may not be as big of a household name as other election hopefuls whose seats hang in the balance.But his is a red safe seat with a high profile, as the former seat of Tony Blair .The seat is predicted to go Tory by a whisker, handing power to Paul Sewell, which would see Labour lost the seat to its rivals for the first time since .  The previous MRP poll had Labour to lose  seats to the Conservatives, but that has now dropped to . Both partiesapos leaders are hot-footing it around the country as they visit five marginal seats each in their final push to win swing votersapos support ahead of polling day. The final YouGov MRP poll, which correctly called % of seats in , shows the gap between the two major parties narrowing - but predicts a dismal defeat for Labour yet again.  Its final poll before voters head to the ballot boxes tomorrow has the Tories hanging on to power -  but with the partyaposs lead narrowing to a -seat majority.The poll has emerged as Prime Minister Boris Johnson is touring the country pushing his get Brexit done mantra. Meanwhile, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is calling for a vote for hope in his pledge his party will Save the NHS.Both parties are targeting marginal seats in the midlands and north as the race to the ballots looms. In the final poll, voting intentions would see the Conservatives hold with %, Labour with %, the Liberal Democrats with % and the Brexit Party with %. The poll predicts The Tories gaining  seats on aposs General Election result, Labour would lose , the Lib Dems gain three, the Scottish National Party six.While the polls suggest the Tories will still edge back into power, the latest predictions show the gap closing between Labour and the Tories. But the polls donapost predict great leaps for Labour. If the polls are proven accurate on Election Day, it would be the party’s worst performance since .

title: jeremy corbyn asks voters end
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn asks voters to end  years of Tory hell in crucial final hoursThe Labour leader has been on a whistlestop tour of marginal seats in the UK. Mr Corbyn said the UK was at a fork in the roadShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn has urged voters to end the nine years of Tory hell by ­axing lying Boris Johnson today and ­paving the way for a fairer Britain. Speaking to a lively crowd in East London the Labour leader said: “The issues in this election are very profound.Most people say in most election this is the most important elections there’s ever been andyou’re a candidate it always feels that way - trust me I’ve done it ten times. “But the issues in this election are so very, very important, very very profound. We’re literally at a fork in the road.He added: “So when the election comes tomorrow it is a very clear choic e. You go down the road of Boris Johnson, a sweetheart deal with Donald Trump , we break off any serious relationship with Europe.“Or you go down the Labour way, which is the adult responsible way of negotiating a settlement which we will all live by and I will make sure is carried out in a future relationship with Europe. “But we also go down the road of investing our country, investing to end austerity and redistributing wealth and power in our society in a way that’s never been seen before.” The Labour leader insisted only his party would keep the NHS from the clutches of profit-hungry US private firms, tackle poverty and reduce the growing inequality sweeping the country.As he spoke, EU chief Michel Barnier debunked Boris Johnson’s boast that he will “get Brexit done” next year, by warning trade ­negotiations will take far longer.And a new poll showed Labour had closed the gap on the Tories to just %, the smallest since October. Mr Corbyn said: “There’s a choice tomorrow. Either we continue with austerity and the horrible levels of poverty and security that many people face, or you have a ­government that is serious about investing in the future.”  And he added at a meeting in Hoxton, East London: “The choice facing you, the people of this country, tomorrow is truly historic. “The establishment doesn’t want Labour to win. They don’t want a Labour government on the side of the people, shaking up how this country is run. “Boris Johnson will open our NHS to takeover by American mega ­corporations and carry on with more cuts. That’s why Donald Trump wants Boris Johnson to win. Tomorrow you can shock the establishment by voting for hope.  “Hope for yourself. For your family. For your community. For our NHS. For our country. When Labour wins, the nurse wins, the pensioner wins, the student wins, the office worker wins, the ­engineer wins. We all win.” Mr Corbyn called on activists to spend today convincing undecided voters to back Labour, after an ugly ­election campaign marred by disgraceful smears on his character and a string of blatant lies and empty promises by Mr Johnson. He also had a dig at the PM for repeatedly ducking questions – and his latest bid to avoid scrutiny by hiding in a fridge on a milk round. Mr Corbyn, who embarked on a -mile trip speaking to crowds around the land, told a Middlesbrough meeting: “I’ve not come here to deliver milk, or to hide in a fridge.  “I’ve come here with a message of hope. I am determined we go flat out, to get everyone to vote, and hopefully vote Labour and ­recognise in our manesto there is hope, there is something positive. “It is our chance tomorrow to elect a government that will be for the many not the few.” He later added: “We now have had  days of this campaign and  days of unbelievable levels of abuse hurled at leading figures of the Labour Party. Unbelievable levels of character assassinations and I simply say this,you wish to inhabit the gutter, that’s fine by me but I will not be joining you there. We’ve had six weeks in which we’ve been campaigning all over the country. Six weeks in which we’ve been under relentless media assault against my party, ­nevertheless our message has got through.  “A message that we will protect the NHS. We won’t do secret deals with the United States.” Labour Party chair Ian Lavery urged undecided voters to ask themselves, “Which side are you on ” He told activists: “When you knock on people’s doors, when they say they don’t know, ask them are they prepared to see people in the foreseeable future, kids, in poverty.  “Kids going to school with holes in their shoes, kids going to school without the right attire in these freezing cold conditions, not even having food in their bellies, .million kids in poverty  We cannot allow this to continue.” Mr Corbyn started his day in Glasgow, travelled to the North-East then went to Rother Valley and Bedford before a final rally in London.

title: jeremy corbyn delivers message hope
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn delivers message of hope not milk on final day of campaigningThe Labour leader touched down in the marginal seat of Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland on his whistlestop tour after the latest polling showed Boris Johnson on course to win a -seat majorityShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsJeremy Corbyn gave a speech in Middlesbrough "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn announced he was bringing a message of hope as he spoke to hundreds of supporters on the eve of the election in the north east. The Labour leader touched down in the marginal seat of Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, which fell to the Tories last time round, on a whistlestop tour of the United Kingdom hoping to convince voters there to come back to the party. Mr Corbyn, who seemed in good spirits, told those gathered in the cold: Iaposve not come here to deliver milk - or to hide in a fridge, with a dig at the Prime Minister who went on a milkround in the marginal seat of Guiseley, in Yorkshire and hid from cameras in a fridge. Instead the Labour leader declared: Iaposve come here with a message of hope. Mr Corbyn arrived from Glasgow, where he kicked off the final day of campaigning, to a crowd warmed up by Shadow Transport Secretary Andy McDonald who sang his own version of Itaposs Beginning to Look a Lot Like Christmas including the lines Johnsonaposs got to go. While Laura Pidcock, who has a fight on her hands in North West Durham, told supporters to go out and campaign telling them that every conversation over the next few hours will count. She said: “Every single conversation you have had will absolutely be worth it. There are people right now who do not know who they are going to vote for and it our job to have a conversation with every single one of those people who do not know who they are going to vote for and tell them that a better society is possible.”  Labour Party chair Ian Lavery had a more direct challenge to undecided voters telling them it was time to ask themselves which side are you on .He told activists: When you knock on peopleaposs doors in communities up and down the country when they say they donapost know ask them are they prepared to see people in the foreseeable future kids in poverty, kids going to school with holes in their shoes, kids going to school without the right attire in these freezing cold conditions, not even having food in their bellies, .m kids in poverty, lots of them in areas like this We cannot allow this to continue. A smiling Mr Corbyn told activists: “I am utterly determined we go flat out between now and pm tomorrow evening to get everyone to vote, and hopefully vote Labour and recognise in our manesto there is hope, there is something positive.” He urged them to do all they could in these crucial last hours. Mr Corbyn told campaigners: “Please do absolutely everything you can to win in Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, and all the other marginal constituencies. It is our chance tomorrow to elect a government that will be for the many not the few.”  After his brief stop in the north east the Labour leader is travelling across country to the East Midlands ahead of a visit to Bedford and a final rally in London before a home crowd. Labour have an uphill fight to win over undecided voters after the latest polling showed Boris Johnson on track to win a -seat majority. Speaking after the Middlesbrough rally Mr Corbyn refused to speak about the numbers in the YouGov MRP poll.  He said: “I never ever comment on opinion polls the only poll that matters is the one tomorrow.” Askedhe should resignLabour fails to get a majority he replied: “I think you should concentrate on the election and the fact that Labour is going to win the election.” The Labour leader had told activists that he had run a positive campaign slamming the abuse he and the party had received. He said: “We now have had  days of this campaign and  days of unbelievable levels of abuse hurled at leading figures of the Labour Party, unbelievable levels of character assassinations going on against our party and our movement and I simply say this,you wish to inhabit the gutter, that’s absolutely fine by me but I will not be joining you there. Asked why he believed that he was still on course to enter Number , he replied: “We’ve had six weeks in which we’ve been campaigning all over the country six weeks in which we’ve been under relentless media assault against my party nevertheless our message has got through a message that we will protect the NHS we won’t do secret deals with the United States”.

story: NewsJeremy Corbyn has reached nearly k people online - and reached beyond his baseEXCLUSIVE: Some , people who have interacted with Jeremy Corbyns online posts are newcomers to the party - showing hes been able to reach out beyond his core baseShareCommentsByChris Stokel-Walker:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNearly , people have interacted with the Labour leaderaposs posts in this campaign.And , are newcomers to Labour ’s social media presence – which the party claims shows Labour has been able to reach out beyond its core base.“Labour have changed up their approach this election, they are far more combative and have energised a dference segment of the electorate to say  or even ,” said Tristan Hotham, a social media researcher at the University of Bath, who has studied the parties’ social media campaigning.Labour sources claim it has been a successful digital campaign for the party this year: Labouraposs eight-strong digital team has five times the number of video views on Twitter , and % more shares of content on Facebook , than it did in the  election.The most popular video the Labour Party has produced was Rob Delaney’s impassioned plea for the National Health Service , which has been seen by . million people.  Part of that popularity was driven by paid promotion of the video, says Hotham. He estimates the party spent up to £, promoting the American actor’s video on Facebook so it was seen . million times. “They have been kickstarting what more naturally occurred in ,” said Hotham, who estimates that the party has doubled spending on Facebook ad campaigns compared to . Who Targets Me, which has been tracking social media posts during the election campaign, has tracked the amount each party has to spend per impression for their online adverts on Facebook. Labour and Jeremy Corbyn have  paid twice the amount  other major political pages to promote their adverts in the last month. This comes as  New Scientist reported  that political campaigns in the United States have to pay up to three times as much to promote adverts on Facebook to people with opposing viewpoints. In all, videos on Jeremy Corbyn’s personal Facebook page have been seen nearly  million times – more than the  million views recorded in the longer  general election campaign.The Labour leader’s Facebook page is four times most influential than his party’s official Facebook presence, which has posted videos seen  million times and shared , times. “The fact that on an old stalwart like Facebook, that Labour can pull in new audiences shows a marked sht in the politics of the Facebook audience,” said Hotham. Hotham did point out that interactions includes comments and interactions, which can be negative as well as positive. While the party leaders criss-crossed the country in the final day of campaigning before polling stations open, the battle was being waged on social media.  Labour’s official Facebook page has earned more than half of the interactions across all political party pages on Wednesday, while the Tories have driven a third of all interactions.But on Instagram , the Conservatives were in the lead, with  percent of interactions the day before the election – twice the number that Labour had.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn today urges Mirror readers to back Labour in tomorrow’s election to end a decade of “cruel” austerity and offer Britain hope for the future. The Labour leader said he “feels the pain” of millions of people trying to get by and is determined to make the country a fairer place. And he made a heartfelt promise to protect the NHS after our stories about desperate families struggling to get treatment from the struggling health service. In his final interview before polling day, Mr Corbyn revealed what put the fire in his belly as he appealed to undecided voters to back him to be the next Prime Minister. “I feel the pain of the people I represent, the pain of trying to bring up children in a small overcrowded flat, and wanting them to do well and wanting them to achieve at school,” he said. “I think of the people saying theyaposve got three children with quite wide age gap sharing a bedroom, one wants to play music, one wants to do their homework, one wants to play with Lego on the floor. “They just end up fighting for space, then those children donapost achieve what they could at school and their whole le path is damaged because we, the community as a whole, did not provide the housing they need. Itaposs that sort of thing that drives me to change things in our society.” Speaking to the Mirror on Labouraposs battlebus in the North West of England, he added: “Le can be cruel to many people and I want us to have a much fairer society.” Mr Corbyn revealed that his first act on becoming PM would be to allocate emergency funding for more hostel places to help those sleeping on the streets. “Iaposll do something urgently about the rough-sleeping crisis around the country as a symbol of what we are determined to do to end the injustice of the housing crisis,” he said. Labour will also prioritise shoring up the NHS in its first weeks in power – after the Mirror published a series of devastating stories about children struggling to get treatment. “It is an utter disgrace in a civilized world, we can do better. It indicates just how desperate the situation is in our health service,” he said.  But he backed away from personally attacking Boris Johnsonaposs handling of the situation. “I would rather go out there and be positive about what we want to achieve. People can make their own judgements on Boris Johnson when confronted with a picture of a child on the floor of the hospital, compared with the approach that we would take.” He praised his shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth as “absolutely brilliant” despite a leaked conversation in which he predicted they would lose the election as a result of Brexit and Mr Corbynaposs leadership. The Labour leader revealed Mr Ashworth had called him up straight away and was “mortied” and “very upset” that his “banter” had been published. “Heaposs working flat out for a Labour government. I know that and I think heaposs been absolutely brilliant on health and I think we just move on,” Mr Corbyn said. But he acknowledged candidatesapos concerns that Labouraposs Brexit policy was coming up regularly on the doorstep in Leave seats. He admitted that many people were “fed up” with Brexit but that any deal needed to be one that protected people’s livelihoods and security. “Iaposm sure many people are fed up and bored with it,” he said. “Iaposve had as my bottom line that I would prevent a no deal Brexit and would prevent a trade deal with Donald Trump that would sell off our public services.” He admitted it was going to be “dficult” to resolve the issue once and for all but he wanted to try to represent both the % and % as it was the “sensible, grown-up” approach. “I recognise that itaposs going to be dficult. I donapost want to represent just the % or the %, I want to represent the people as a whole”. A Labour government would spend three months negotiating a Leave deal with the EU that wouldnapost destroy industry and then put it – and Remain – to a public confirmatory vote in six months. Its negotiating team would include Brexiteer Labour MPs as well as Remainer ones. “It will be people who have dfering views,” he said. But he admitted his decision not to campaign for either side was “not easy”. He added: “What  could we as a party do to represent people who voted both ways in the referendum  Anything  would be even harder.”  And he warned that under Boris Johnson the risk of a damaging no deal Brexit at the end of  was very high. Mr Corbyn, who has been accused of not being tough enough on security, insisted the first job of any government was to “keep the country safe and secure”. He talked passionately about the welfare of armed forces personnel and cited their pride in missions including rescuing refugees, dealing with the Ebola crisis and UN peacekeeping. “Our armed services are there, yes to protect us against attack, but also there to deal with the insecurities that come from poverty, from environmental disaster and from refugee flows.” Asked whether he could envisage a scenario where he would be prepared to deploy troops for security reasons, he replied: “I would hope we didnapost have to, but of course you have to be prepared to defend society”. Throughout his leadership, Mr Corbyn has faced allegations of not dealing with anti-semitism in party ranks swtly or tough enough. “Antisemitism is utterly evil. Obviously weaposll continue to clamp down on it,” he said. He suggested that Labour could adopt recommendations from the ongoing Equality and Human Rights Commission inquiry in full. “Theyaposre only looking at processes and so yes... Weaposd look at it of course. I would imagine we would implement them but theyaposve not made any suggestions yet.” Mr Corbyn was last week accused of being unpatriotic for not watching the Queenaposs Christmas message – but claried that he had watched news bulletins in the morning. “When her Majesty finally gets to make the speech we all know whataposs in it because weaposve seen the trails on it. There was a bit of miscommunication between the interviewer and myself on that. I think weaposre now cool.” He and we Laura Alez, who was sitting next to him on the battle bus, would celebrate Christmas together “hopefully in No , thataposs the idea”. He claimed that “we both” do the cooking but was interrupted by his we who added: “Mainly me”. What was he getting her for Christmas  “A present.” They laughed. “Something nice and something surprising”. But would he have the time to go shopping  “I make time. If you want something done, ask a busy person.” Mr Corbyn claimed he was able to cope with the scale of personal abuse he sometimes faced from the media – but that he worried about his family. “It gets to people around me more than it does me. It is very stressful for family and friends who get very angry on my behalf and feel thereaposs been a lot of unfairness. “I have been active in politics all of my le and I do it because I believe in it. You get personal abuse. Iaposm not replying to it, Iaposm not getting into the gutter with anybody.” He did not criticise Labour candidates for choosing not to put his name or picture on leaflets. “Itaposs up to them what they put on their literature. Nothing bothers me. The only thing that bothers me is winning the election. Itaposs not a Presidential election, itaposs a parliamentary election and Iaposm proud to be Leader of the party.” Mr Corbyn ruled out endorsing tactical voting but admitted he was “looking forward” to seeing Iain Duncan Smith, the architect of universal credit, lose his seat to his Labour rival.  “Iaposm not in favour of tactical voting. I want the Labour message to be there clearly all across the country.” He has ruled out forming a coalition in the event of a hung Parliament and asked whether he would stand downhe lost insisted: “I donapost intend to lose”. But after shadow chancellor John McDonnell appealed for the next Labour leader to be a woman, Mr Corbyn yesterday admitted there was a “fair case” for that to happen. He also hopes that in the future there would be two Labour deputies – a man and a woman. Mr Corbyn revealed the first thing he would do on walking through the famous black door of No  would be to check out the coffee machine – so he would be equipped to work late into the night.

story: NewsJeremy Corbyn urges voters to end nine years of Tory hell and boot out JohnsonEXCLUSIVE: The leader of the Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn has urged the British public to vote for his party to end almost a decade of Conservative Party rule while kicking out Boris JohnsonShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsLabour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn speaks during a final general election campaign event in London "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn has urged voters to end the nine years of Tory hell by ­axing lying Boris Johnson today and ­paving the way for a fairer Britain.The Labour leader insisted only his party would keep the NHS from the clutches of profit-hungry US private firms, tackle poverty and reduce the growing inequality sweeping the country.As he spoke, EU chief Michel Barnier ­shattered Boris Johnson’s boast that he will “get Brexit done” next year by warning trade ­negotiations could take longer.And a new poll showed Labour had closed the gap on the Tories to just %, the smallest since October. Mr Corbyn said: “There’s a choice tomorrow. Either we continue with austerity and the horrible levels of poverty and security that many people face or you have a ­government that is serious about investing in the future.” And he added at a meeting in Hoxton, East London: “The choice facing you, the people of this country, tomorrow is truly historic. “The establishment doesn’t want Labour to win. They don’t want a Labour government on the side of the people, shaking up how this country is run.“Boris Johnson will open our NHS to takeover by American mega ­corporations and carry on with more cuts. That’s why Donald Trump wants Boris Johnson to win. Tomorrow you can shock the establishment, by voting for hope.“Hope for yourself. For your family. For your community. For our NHS. For our country. When Labour wins, the nurse wins, the pensioner wins, the student wins, the office worker wins, the ­engineer wins. We all win.” Mr Corbyn called on activists to spend today convincing undecided voters to back Labour, after an ugly ­election campaign marred by disgraceful smears on his character and a string of blatant lies and empty promises by Mr Johnson. He also had a dig at the PM for repeatedly ducking questions – and his latest bid to avoid scrutiny by hiding in a fridge on a milk round. Mr Corbyn, who embarked on a -mile trip speaking to crowds around the land, told a Middlesbrough meeting: “I’ve not come here to deliver milk, or to hide in a fridge. “I’ve come here with a message of hope. I am determined we go flat out, to get everyone to vote, and hopefully vote Labour and ­recognise in our manesto there is hope, there is something positive. “It is our chance tomorrow to elect a government that will be for the many not the few.”  He later added: “We now have had  days of this campaign and  days of unbelievable levels of abuse hurled at leading figures of the Labour Party. Unbelievable levels of character assassinations and I simply say this,you wish to inhabit the gutter, that’s fine by me but I will not be joining you there. We’ve had six weeks in which we’ve been campaigning all over the country six weeks in which we’ve been under relentless media assault against my party, ­nevertheless our message has got through. A message that we will protect the NHS we won’t do secret deals with the United States.” Labour Party chair Ian Lavery urged undecided voters to ask themselves “which side are you on”  He told activists: “When you knock on people’s doors when they say they don’t know ask them are they prepared to see people in the foreseeable future kids in poverty. “Kids going to school with holes in their shoes, kids going to school without the right attire in these freezing cold conditions, not even having food in their bellies, .million kids in poverty  We cannot allow this to continue.” Mr Corbyn started his day in Glasgow, travelled to the North East then went to Rother Valley and Bedford before a final rally in London.  A new Savanta ComRes poll for Thenewspaper showed the Tories unchanged on % but Labour up three percentage points to %. It came after a previous poll had predicted Mr Johnson was on track to win a -seat majority. Mr ­Johnson’s boast about forging trade deals with the EU by the end of next year were blown apart by Mr Barnier last night. In a leaked recording, the EU’s chief negotiator told a private meeting the -month timetable is “unrealistic”.
